name: Zencoder
label: Integrated, customizable, and intuitive coding agent
maker_introduction:
üìå
I‚Äôm Andrew, the Founder of Zencoder. In my previous organization, despite having a large engineering team with hundreds of people, we could only implement a small fraction of our ideas. Imagine how much more value we would generate if we could innovate 10 times faster. We built Zencoder to help you ship better products faster. Our coding and testing agents help developers spend less time on routine and more time creating amazing things.

We support 70+ programming languages and integrate seamlessly with VS Code, JetBrains and Android Studio, offering robust support for technologies and frameworks. Our AI research team constantly benchmarks Zencoder‚Äôs AI agents to push them toward state-of-the-art performance. As of March 2025, we‚Äôre at 60%+ on SWE-Bench-Verified and ~30%+ on SWE-Bench-Multimodal(#1), delivering best-in-class coding assistance right inside your IDE.

Beyond coding, we offer 20+ DevOps integrations (making us the most integrated coding agent)‚Äîincluding JIRA, Sentry, GitHub, and GitLab‚Äîto help you ship faster. To help you ship better, we've built a unit testing agent for maintainable, high-quality code. With our AI Agents, speed and quality can come together; you don't have to pick one. Our unique Repo Grokking technology helps Zencoder better understand large codebases, generate, test, repair, and refine code, making your workflow smoother than ever. We‚Äôd love your feedback‚Äîwhat do you love, what needs tweaking, and which features do you want to see next? Thanks for stopping by.

Do join our community on Slack and Discord

Vibor Cipan
Maker
@andrewsthoughts @masump Hey Masum, that's literally what we do. We have a robust technology (Agentic Pipeline) that will go through several steps. So, instead of just spitting out the first things that come to LLM's "mind," we run a series of steps.

We start with code validation and testing
Our pipeline checks generated code against your codebase, not just general syntax rules. Before generating any code, we run syntax and code correction, check imports and dependencies, and validate within your project's specifics.

Then, we'll do an Automated Repair Loop.
When issues are detected, agents don't give up - they initiate repair cycles. The pipeline diagnoses problems, applies fixes, and re-validates until the code meets quality thresholds - bringing you to the production-level code quality.

And it powers all our agents through our Unified Agent Infra
So, essentially the same validation pipeline powers all our specialized agents. Whether generating new files, or making changes to existing ones, or making unit tests, each agent benefits from the context of your repository and continuous improvement cycles.

Thanks for your comment. If you are interested in joining our communities, I'd like to invite you to join our community on Slack and Discord.

Share
14h ago
Vibor Cipan
Maker
@simona_o_neill3 that's a fair question and I'll try to give a meaningful answer!

While Zencoder works great even for people who are not pro engineers, people who are technical or semi-technical generally get the most out of it. That being said, for example, I don't know much about Kotlin mobile app development, but I was able to use Zencoder in Android Studio to build some mobile apps.

One of the most significant differences between us and just using one LLM is the fact that we are eliminating the entire process of copy-pasting different file versions, and you have it all in one nice and professional IDE. Even if you need to team up with pro engineers later on, they can take the code and environment over easily.
Additionally, we are not using just one model. In the background, we rely on a family of different models, each primed for specific tasks. We have 5-9 models and their instances running at any given moment based on different tasks.

So, while Model A can be excellent for code generation, it might be less optimal for code completion than Model B. So, we follow the "best tool for the job" approach and dynamically, in the background, figure out which models to use for you - so for one subscription, you are getting a bunch of models, each optimized for specific tasks.
Also, we have something called an agentic pipeline. So instead of just using the code that Claude spits out (and you might need to fix), we will first try running it, check for its syntax correctness, do some reviews and even self-repair it so you don't end up with the first thing that comes to LLMs' "mind" but code that's at or very, very close to the production level.

Hope this helps and gives you some context.

Also, if you are interested in joining our communities, I'd like to invite you to join our community on Slack and Discord.

name: The DuckDB Local UI
label: Easily explore local data files with DuckDB
maker_introduction:
üìå
DuckDB is fairly new to the modern data scene, but it has quickly become the go-to choice for developers, analysts, and data engineers who want a fast, efficient, local analytics workflow.

Today, we‚Äôre proud to share a first-class UI experience for DuckDB, a project built in collaboration with DuckDB Labs to support the broader DuckDB community.

This lightweight, intuitive interface makes it easier than ever to explore data, write queries, and get instant insights, all powered by DuckDB.

After three years of working with DuckDB, I continue to be surprised by its speed, power, and simplicity. I'm thrilled to introduce another way to make DuckDB even more accessible for everyone, from individual analysts to large data teams.

We‚Äôd love for you to take a quack at the DuckDB UI and let us know what you think.
